content.body: Btw, re symbols, I'm still surprised no engine considers registered symbols separately from unique symbols, and simply implements them as a wrapped string. At that point there is no need to track instances of registered symbols and collect them, at least any more than roping the strings they wrap, and `Symbol.for` can simply recreate the value, `Symbol.keyFor` can unwrap the description, and comparing would match the subtype (registered symbol) + description value.
content.formatted_body: Btw, re symbols, I'm still surprised no engine considers registered symbols separately from unique symbols, and simply implements them as a wrapped string. At that point there is no need to track instances of registered symbols and collect them, at least any more than roping the strings they wrap, and Symbol.for can simply recreate the value, Symbol.keyFor can unwrap the description, and comparing would match the subtype (registered symbol) + description value.
